content.raw:
The CloudSim machine's database is corrupt or it does not contain any information about the constellation cxe378f80a. 

Please verify that constellation cxe378f80a was created from that CloudSim instance (54.242.249.62). This should be the case, since things were working before.

The next thing to do is to log in the CloudSim instance. You will need the ssh keys available via the "ssh key download" link at the top right corner of CloudSim (you must be logged in with admin privileges).

Once in the CloudSim instance, use the root account (sudo su) to look for the following directory:


```
#!python

/var/www-cloudsim-auth/machines/cxe378f80a
```

You should be able to find the keys to your machines there.

Then, look for


```
#!python

/tmp/cloudsimd.log
```

This could give a clue to what may have happened. Can you send the content?

You can also stop and start the daemon by running:


```
#!python

sudo stop cloudsimd

and

sudo start cloudsimd

```

Its important to note that you don't need CloudSim to use the constellation machines. However, what you are experiencing is not normal and we should find the cause for this problem. Next steps could involve adding an osrf user to the admin list.
content.html:
The CloudSim machine's database is corrupt or it does not contain any information about the constellation cxe378f80a.

Please verify that constellation cxe378f80a was created from that CloudSim instance (54.242.249.62). This should be the case, since things were working before.

The next thing to do is to log in the CloudSim instance. You will need the ssh keys available via the "ssh key download" link at the top right corner of CloudSim (you must be logged in with admin privileges).

Once in the CloudSim instance, use the root account (sudo su) to look for the following directory:

/var/www-cloudsim-auth/machines/cxe378f80a

You should be able to find the keys to your machines there.

Then, look for

/tmp/cloudsimd.log

This could give a clue to what may have happened. Can you send the content?

You can also stop and start the daemon by running:

sudo stop cloudsimd

and

sudo start cloudsimd

Its important to note that you don't need CloudSim to use the constellation machines. However, what you are experiencing is not normal and we should find the cause for this problem. Next steps could involve adding an osrf user to the admin list.

content.raw:
Another thing to try is to point your browser to 


```
#!python

54.242.249.62/cloudsim/inside/cgi-bin/constellations/cxe378f80a
```

This should give you an idea of what is the database for that constellation. It is the REST url to access constellation information. You need to be logged with the browser in order to get useful information.
content.html:

This should give you an idea of what is the database for that constellation. It is the REST url to access constellation information. You need to be logged with the browser in order to get useful information.

content.raw:
I am a bit afraid to stop the simulation and not to be able to start it again.
We are using the constellation without the console but the console helps ....

Note that entering with 54.242.249.62/cloudsim/inside/cgi-bin/constellations/cxe378f80a didn't help either. Same results.

I can give you access to the constellation, I want very much to be able to correct the situation. 
Thanks
